support_summary: In response to DNA damage, PARP1 becomes activated and synthesizes Poly(ADP-ribose) (PAR) polymers. TDP-43 is recruited to sites of DNA damage and directly binds to these PAR polymers, which triggers its translocation to the cytoplasm.

functions.cellular_process: In response to cellular stress such as oxidative damage, the DNA damage sensor Poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase 1 (PARP1) becomes hyperactivated. This leads to the synthesis of Poly(ADP-ribose) (PAR) polymers, which can bind directly to TDP-43.
functions.effect_description: Stress-induced PARP1 activation triggers the cytoplasmic translocation of TDP-43 from the nucleus, a key step in the formation of pathological cytoplasmic aggregates.
biological_consequence: Cellular stress (e.g., oxidative damage) → PARP1 hyperactivation at DNA damage sites → Synthesis of Poly(ADP-ribose) (PAR) polymers → PAR polymers bind nuclear TDP-43 → TDP-43 translocation to the cytoplasm → Formation of cytoplasmic aggregates & neurotoxicity.
specific_effects: Oxidative stress-induced translocation of TDP-43 to the cytoplasm is dependent on PARP-1 activation. [2]
Pharmacological inhibition of PARP-1 blocked the cytosolic translocation of TDP-43 in response to stressors like MNNG and oxygen-glucose deprivation. [2, 14]
TDP-43 is recruited to sites of DNA double-strand breaks as a component of the nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ) repair pathway. [18, 22]

evidence.paper_title: PARP-1 activation leads to cytosolic accumulation of TDP-43 in neurons
evidence.authors: Joshua M Marcus, Mohammed I Hossain, Jean-Philippe Gagné, Guy G Poirier, Lori L McMahon, Rita M Cowell, Shaida A Andrabi
evidence.relevant_quote: ...we used N-methyl-N-nitroso-N'-nitroguanidine (MNNG) and oxygen-glucose deprivation (OGD) in mouse neuronal cultures to activate PARP-1 and observed that pharmacological inhibition of PARP-1 blocked the cytosolic translocation of TDP-43.

evidence.paper_title: Motor neuron disease-associated loss of nuclear TDP-43 is linked to DNA double-strand break repair defects
evidence.authors: Jayalakshmi Mitra, Dibyadeep Datta, Anwesha Sanyal, Anindyajit Banerjee, Souvik Ghosh, Subhasis Das, Goutam Chandra, Subhamita Roy, Suman Kumar Das, Atanu Duttaroy, Nitai P Bhattacharyya, Hemanta K Majumder
evidence.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
evidence.relevant_quote: Here, we have documented TDP-43's involvement in DDR as a key component of nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ), the major pathway for repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) in the postmitotic neurons.

summary: TDP43 activates PARP1 to modulate tdp-43 cytoplasmic translocation (stress-induced), ultimately affecting formation of cytoplasmic aggregates & neurotoxicity.
